verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: As elsewhere, God’s instructions to Moses establish divine authority and direct guidance for order among His people.

verses.text: "Speak to the Israelites, saying: If a woman conceives and bears a male child, she will be ceremonially unclean for seven days; just as in the days of her menstrual impurity, she will be unclean."
verses.comment: The pattern of ritual purity echoes God’s concern for holiness and the distinct spiritual purpose in the laws handed down to Israel. The reference to uncleanness links back to the realities of bodily life and its connection to spiritual realities.

verses.text: And on the eighth day the child’s flesh shall be circumcised.
verses.comment: Circumcision on the eighth day initiates the child into the covenant, prefiguring spiritual cleansing and the deeper meanings later given to spiritual rebirth. See also Christ’s presentation at the temple (Luke 2:21), highlighting fulfillment in the New Testament.

verses.text: Then she shall remain in the blood of her purification for thirty-three days. She shall not touch anything holy, nor come into the sanctuary, until her days of purification are completed.
verses.comment: The extended days emphasize both physical and spiritual preparation before re-entering sacred space. This anticipates mysteries of spiritual purification and readiness for close encounter with God—a theme intimately tied to later sacramental theology.

verses.text: But if she gives birth to a female child, then she shall be unclean for two weeks, as in her impurity, and she shall remain in the blood of her purification for sixty-six days.
verses.comment: The longer period for a female child may reflect ancient symbolism of spiritual fruitfulness and anticipation of future generations. The numbers also have spiritual significance; see also numerological themes in biblical typology.

verses.text: "When the days of her purification are fulfilled, whether for a son or a daughter, she shall bring to the priest at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting a year-old lamb for a burnt offering, and a young pigeon or a turtledove for a sin offering."
verses.comment: Atonement and thanksgiving are both required—the lamb and dove symbolizing cleansing and peace. See the Blessed Mother’s obedience to this law in Luke 2:22-24, illustrating both fulfillment and humility.

verses.text: "He shall offer it before the LORD and make atonement for her, and then she will be clean from the flow of her blood. These are the regulations for her who gives birth, whether to a male or a female child."
verses.comment: Priestly mediation for purification is a recurring theme throughout the Old Testament, pointing towards the need for spiritual intercession and atonement—a foundation carried forward into the New Covenant reality of sacramental grace.

verses.text: "If she cannot afford a lamb, she shall bring two turtledoves or two young pigeons, one for a burnt offering and the other for a sin offering. The priest shall make atonement for her, and she shall be clean."
verses.comment: Provision for the poor reveals God’s mercy and inclusivity in worship, allowing all to receive purification regardless of social standing. This principle is seen fulfilled in Mary and Joseph’s humble offering (Luke 2:24). Christological implications manifest as Jesus is later presented by His Mother under these same precepts, fulfilling the Law and inaugurating new grace.
